Carl Strange wrote:

>I kicked around a few ideas for a project, many getting wildly out of
>hand, and settled on Braille character recognition.  It let me play
>with a bit of development while using your OCR experiment as a
>framework.  
>
At this point I should point out to the viewers at home that the 'OCR' 
experiment in SharpNEAT isn't proper OCR. The input patterns are fixed 
(1 for each lower case letter of the alphabet) and so the problem is 
actually a pattern classification problem, which is far simpler then 
proper OCR. In fact it should be possible to solve with a feedforward 
only network and backpropagation.

>I thought the reduced 7 X 5 input grid and very distinct
>character set would be a snap for the network.  Now I know better. 
>Thirty-five inputs and twenty-six outputs is too much for a one-to-one
>connected net so the problem isn't trivial.
>
What do you mean by one-to-one? Or is that just the topology of the 
starting networks? (connection proportion = 1.0).

>  I'm having fun playing
>with the various search parameters, especially the frequency of "add
>connections" and "add nodes".
>  
>
If you have the latest code I think the OCR experiment has a customised 
NeatParameters object. As I recall the experiment performed better with 
a higher 'add connection' rate, and with pruning switched on. That way 
the population cycles between networks with loads of connections and 
networks with very few - the complexity zig zags.

As you say braille characters are more distictive than normal (visual) 
characters so I would also expect this to make the problem to be easier 
to solve. I'm just looking at the braille characters here:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Braille

...and I note that they are just 3x2 dots. How did you come to be using 
7x5? Are these in fact images of braille characters?

If the problem really is too difficult then it can be decomposed into 26 
simpler problems, that is evolve a network for each character you want 
to recognise and that that gives a yes/no response. Of course this means 
that to recognise characters you have to run the input past 26 networks 
instead of one - and in fact for pattern classification you may as well 
just compare the inputs with the 26 expected input patterns! But the 
technique has merit when doing proper OCR where the input images vary.

>The downside of adding an experiment is my SharpNEAT library and some
>of the Form1 initialization differ from the standard release.
>  
>
Yeh the experiments should probably be external to the library, and 
there should really be a mechanism for experiments to 'plug-in' to the 
main application instead of having to manually add them into the Form1 
class. I never said it was perfect ;)

Colin
